summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in a civil injunctive action brought by the SEC in April 2014.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Little Rock, Arkansas, alleges that defendants Danny Brown and Toni Boydston violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the complaint, Brown and Boydston failed to maintain adequate insurance coverage on the Mayflower property and failed to convert the $450,000 check to the $10,000 insurance check.  Brown also failed to disclose to the court that he had converted the check into an actual-cash-value insurance check and that he was liable for $230,000 in punitive damages for the same amount.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC's Complaint, Brown consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the federal securities laws and orders him to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties equal to the amount of his ill-gotten gains.  In a parallel action, the SEC today announced that it has obtained a court order halting the asset-purchase and sale of Mayflower RV.  It also issued an order suspending Brown from appearing before the SEC as an attorney and ordering him to comply with the court's order.  On May 9, 2018, the U. S. District Judge for the Northern District of Arkansas entered a judgment against Brown, finding that Brown violated the securities registration provisions of Sections 5(a)(1) and 5(c) and ordering Brown to pay a civil penalty of $250,000.  Additionally, the court found that Brown was liable as a party to a civil action for breach of contract for his conduct in connection with the purchase of a home and for the payment of a mortgage on the same property.   The court also found Brown liable for prejudgment interests based on his receipt of the check and, thus, granted him the right to redeem the check as an accord and satisfaction of all the parties' claims against him.  For further information, see Litigation Release Order No. 17-cv-8221 (2014).  The complaint also alleges that Brown and his wife, Toni, failed to adequately represent to the SEC that they were not entitled to the same level of compensation as they were entitled to under the lease.
